label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 9, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, recounting the events of a movie he had seen the previous evening, telling her of his morning and breakfast at the Bachelor Officers Quarters (BOQ), and discussing taxes. Sidney continues in his letter to describe an upcoming trip to shoot skeet with a friend and a book he had recently flipped through about the battle of Guadalcanal.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
March 9, 1943
Gertie Darling, 
It is winter here now. Last night the wind
howled around our apartment and the ventian blinds rattled and
banged loke machine guns. The rain drumxed against the black out
panes with that heavy beat of big drops that you get only in
sub tropical countries and the air was wet with moisture so
that I pulled the blanket around my neck instead of the damp .
sheet. This morning there were no lights and we dressed in
the darkness groaning about the hardships of war and our fate.
However after prunes, hot cakes, sausages, and fried eggs at the
BOQ I felt better and with my little razor in my pocket continue
onto the office. There Iplugged my razor into the circuit,
put my feet on the desk and shaved as I talked to the Yeoman
and heard the latest news. fNow I mm once more presentable,
The captain has passed into his office so I have put all the
dummy papers away and seizing my typewriter am wr[i]ting to you.
Last night we [w]ent to the movies and saw Monte
Wooly in the"Pled Piper!" It is a story of an Englisman caught
in France by the opening of the war, and how on his way back to
England he picks up homeless stray children and brings them with
him. Wooly gives the best example of top notch acting that I
have seen in years, and the children with him are superb.
Should youhave the opportunity to see it do not fail to do so.
It was so comfortable sitting in an upholstered chair and
listening to the accompanyng music that I hated when £The End"
flashed on the screen andeveryone filed out. I hadthought the
movies wonderful at the gunnery school and there we had sat on
wooden benches without backs, so that seeing a movie while
sunk in the luxuory of what was practically a love seat was
almost to much.
Morris tel[L]s me that the theatres have dropped off
as a result of the ban on motor-cars but he is not worried, says
everything swings back and forth and they will come back again ,
if they do not go the other way. I must say that they have done
wonderfuly and if he did not have to pay such big tadshe would,
be ableto put money aside. However I guess that little baby
will dispose of any suppluxse[s]. Speaking of taxes I wish
Miss Finucan would pull herself together and send me mine to
sign. Also she has never sent meva monthly statement of my
hooks since November. Appartenly she works on the idea, out
of sight out of mind. If you see her tell her for Gods sake to
pop up, Muck has sent Morris all his information and she is
running all the theatres besides.
We have not he rd a word from Armant so do not
[End Page 1]
know whetehr he is comming out here or not. It. begins to look
as if again there has been a lot of talk by the Captains and
nothing comes of it. The more I sec of it all the more I 
realize that there isea great deal of hot air, and the mbracle
of it all is that aminltion is being made and planes do come
off the assembl[y] line.
Do you remember a man called Reginald Sinclair,
he came over on the boat with me and is now the head of
the Kaneohe shooting school. He has asked Morris and I
to go over on Wednesday andshoot Skeet ther[e] and it should
be greet fun. Apparently the way they teach the gunners in
ae[r]oplanes to hit things that are moving is to start them off
with a shot gun so thatthey get the idea of leading an
object. If I shoo_t as badly with a shot gun as I did with
the anti aircraft gun I will be disgraced and will be forced
to hang my head in shame. However the ride over the Pali
is lovely and the other side of the islandis sox green
and attrractive that I will rtsk the loss of prestige just
to see it again.
Morris bought Guadal Canal Diary yesterday and
I glanced through it and thought it the best reading I have
seen in a long time. The discription of how both sides mow
each other down w th machine gun and tank fire is terrific.
But it cannot compare with the march oftime picture we saw at
the movie. The fighting in Russia. You cannot believe lt.
This was no fake. Men drop ing as they charge. Tanks blo ing UP
and then you get a close up of soldiers lying dead in the flames
of the tanks or moving slightly as the flames eat around them.
One German is ccmmlng out of a tank with his hands up and as
he comes clear they pot him with a tommy gun. Really a ghstly
picture but it gives you and idea of what war is really like.
See it if you can.
Goodbye dear, with all myx love
Sidney
[End Page 2]
